image.altText: A police car and a footpath.

items.synopsis: A 15-year-old boy is taken into custody after he allegedly fired a gun in the car park of a Perth school, sending the college and nearby businesses into lockdown.

title.children: School, daycare centre locked down after teenager allegedly fires gun in college carpark

image.altText: A woman stands in front of a window with a sheer curtain, in shadow

items.synopsis: Becoming homeless has meant "Joanne" and her kids have lived in six hotels, two shelters and one caravan park in three years. Her family is part of an increasing number of people struggling to find shelter in Tasmania.

title.children: Buying food from servos and no room for toys, life for a homeless mum and kids living in hotels is a struggle

image.altText: Jenny, dressed in a green and blue knitted top, stands in the kitchen and holds a mobile phone to her ear.

items.synopsis: Over a four-hour phone call, scammers gained access to Jenny's computer and transferred $300,000 out of her account. By the time she alerted the bank, it was too late.

title.children: 'Money mules' are working in teams and make up the majority of scams reported in Australia

image.altText: A man in a suit stands up in parliament and points his finger while talking

items.synopsis: Tasmania's Premier did not have to agree to debate Tuesday's no-confidence motion in parliament over the AFL stadium deal, but in a marathon session every MP had a say. It's a sign of a government under pressure, says Adam Langenberg.

title.children: As expected, Jeremy Rockliff survived a no confidence motion. So what was the point?

image.altText: Police cars blocking a street

items.synopsis: Four police officers have been injured while trying to stop an allegedly stolen truck on the Darling Downs in Queensland. Two were seriously hurt.

title.children: Police officers seriously injured as stolen truck rams their car near Toowoomba

image.altText: Justin Reeves wears a suit

items.synopsis: Hawthorn chief executive Justin Reeves quits the club, telling the board he wishes to "prioritise his mental health and wellbeing" in the wake of a turbulent nine months for the club.

title.children: Hawthorn chief executive Justin Reeves quits club 'to prioritise mental health'

image.altText: Lines of men sitting inside barbed wire wearing identical blue uniforms.

items.synopsis: Australia imports more than $25 billion in goods that may have used modern slavery, and for the first time solar panels are one of the most valuable, according to a human rights group funded by Andrew Forrest.

title.children: Scourge of slavery looms large as Forrest calls out Australia's solar supply chains

image.altText: Brittany Higgins walking alongside another woman, with a man walking behind her.

items.synopsis: A senior police officer has walked back his criticism of ACT Victims of Crime Commissioner Heidi Yates acting as a support person for Brittany Higgins.

title.children: Senior cop walks back claims Brittany Higgins's support person was 'inappropriate'

image.altText: A smiling woman in black t-shirt,  sits with arms wrapped around a smiling girl in glasses, blue t-shirt, logo on left shoulder.

items.synopsis: With limited health services, anyone expecting a baby has to leave Flinders Island before their due date. A community leader says it is "really sad for women who are pregnant."

title.children: Sienna, 9, is unique among her peers. She is the only child born in her remote community

image.altText: Cassius holds a sign with his name on it that he welded

items.synopsis: Jack Brearley, Aleesha Gilmore, Mitchell Colin Forth and Brodie Lee Palmer will face trial in the WA Supreme Court after pleading not guilty to murdering the Indigenous schoolboy in Perth.

title.children: Four people deny murder of teenager Cassius Turvey and are committed to stand trial

image.altText: Narendra Modi raises his finger as he talks into microphones with flags behind him

items.synopsis: Narendra Modi says Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has assured him there will be "strict action" against Sikh separatist groups in Australia, which have been agitating for an independent state in India.

title.children: Albanese promises 'swift action' on temple vandals: Modi

image.altText: An illustration of a hot pink pill with blue and black liquid pouring out

items.synopsis: A new kind of ADHD clinic is cashing in on surging demand for diagnoses — and promising salaries of more than $900,000 to recruit psychiatrists.

title.children: 'I thought it was a typo': Patients charged up to $3,000, doctors offered $900,000 salaries to work online in ADHD diagnosis explosion

image.altText: A close-up of a white boat on the water in flames, with black smoke billowing out.

items.synopsis: Police say the two Melbourne men, aged 61 and 59, jumped from the motor cruiser into the water with life jackets before the boat was engulfed by flames.

title.children: Rescuers pull two people from water after boat goes up in flames in Melbourne's bay

image.altText: Israel Folau looks down wearing red Tonga kit

items.synopsis: World XV coach Steve Hansen claims the selection of Israel Folau can help highlight inclusion after the RFU says it will fly the pride flag at Twickenham on Sunday.

title.children: Twickenham to fly rainbow pride flag after Israel Folau selection

image.altText: A close-up of Dianne Feinstein.

items.synopsis: Dianne Feinstein is one of just two senators representing the 40 million people of California. But at 89 and struggling with poor health, many Democrats are asking if she's up to the job.

title.children: One of the most powerful women in America is ill and seemingly confused. Should she step down?

image.altText: Donald Trump in blue suit and red tie speaking at podium with US flag in the background.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump's criminal trial will start in March, during the heat of next year's presidential primary season.

title.children: Trump labels decision to start criminal trial in March 2024 as 'election interference'

image.altText: Xi Jinping raises his glass and proposes a toast while standing behind a lecturn in front of Chinese flags.

items.synopsis: While the leaders of the G7 met in Japan, Chinese President Xi Jinping used a China-Central Asia Summit to push further economic and trade ties along the old Silk Road under the banner of his signature policy — the Belt and Road Initiative. So how is the project tracking and can it challenge US global influence?

title.children: Xi Jinping's Belt and Road Initiative has cost more than $1 trillion already — what has that much money bought?

image.altText: On the left a magnified photography of the emperor on the right is the watch

items.synopsis: The rare Patek Philippe watch belonged to Qing Dynasty emperor Aisin-Gioro Puyi, who reigned from the age of 2 and was captured by the Red Army in 1945.

title.children: Last emperor of China's watch sells for record price at Hong Kong auction

image.altText: Rolf Harris

items.synopsis: Rolf Harris, the disgraced Australian entertainer who was convicted in 2014 of sexual offences against girls and young women, died nearly two weeks ago, but the details have only just been made public.

title.children: Family kept Rolf Harris's death a secret for almost two weeks

image.altText: Crew stand on the top of a submarine.

items.synopsis: Almost 700 complaints about unacceptable behaviour — including sexual misconduct, bullying and harassment — have been reported within the Royal Australian Navy Fleet Command in the past two years.

title.children: Hundreds of misconduct complaints within Australian navy over two-year period, with most senior ranks involved

image.altText: An aerial view of rows of seated graduation students with colourful sashes over their black academic robes.

items.synopsis: More than 3 million Australians will have their HECS-HELP debts indexed at 7.1 per cent come June 1.

title.children: Thinking of paying off your HECS debt before indexation? The ATO says you better do it tomorrow

image.altText: Paora the Kiwi

items.synopsis: A US zoo stops offering encounters after a video of a kiwi called Paora raises concern among New Zealanders.

title.children: US zoo apologises after treatment of kiwi sparks concern from New Zealanders

image.altText: A composite showing the same street, on the left with a road driving down a car and on the right a person on a bike path.

items.synopsis: From using AI to create more beautiful versions of existing streets to harnessing machine learning to help cities respond to climate change, emerging technology is helping shape the future of our public spaces.

title.children: The artist using AI to turn our cities into 'a place you'd rather live'

image.altText: Commonwealth Bank signage outside Brisbane branch

items.synopsis: The ASX loses ground on US ceiling impasse, CBA lifts variable home loan rates, and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand lifts official rates to 5.5 per cent, the highest in 14 years.

title.children: ASX falls amid stalled US debt ceiling negotiations, CBA lifts mortgage rates again, New Zealand's Reserve Bank raises rates for 12th time

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Iron ore prices fell below $US100 a ton in Singapore as steel prices slumped in China on economic recovery worries. That saw the Australian market drop further and the All Ordinaries index lost 0.7 per cent to 7,393. The ASX 200 index fell 0.6 per cent to 7,214. BHP (-2.2 per cent), Rio Tinto (-2.1 per cent), and Fortescue Metals (-4.1 per cent) all lost ground. Online travel agency Webjet rose 3.8 per cent as it returned to profit for the year on strong travel demand. Jewellery firm Lovisa (-6.9 per cent) was the biggest loser in the ASX 200, while car retailer Eagers Automotive (-4.9 per cent) lost ground as it warned port delays were affecting deliveries. It expects revenue to be $1 billion higher in 2023. Retailer Universal Store (-23.9 per cent) fell the most on the All Ordinaries as it warned that trading conditions had further tightened in April and May, and it expects the subdued environment to continue into 2024.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX market movers

children.content: Iron ore prices fell below $US100 a ton in Singapore as steel prices slumped in China on economic recovery worries.
That saw the Australian market drop further and the All Ordinaries index lost 0.7 per cent to 7,393.
The ASX 200 index fell 0.6 per cent to 7,214.
BHP (-2.2 per cent), Rio Tinto (-2.1 per cent), and Fortescue Metals (-4.1 per cent) all lost ground.
Online travel agency Webjet rose 3.8 per cent as it returned to profit for the year on strong travel demand.
Jewellery firm Lovisa (-6.9 per cent) was the biggest loser in the ASX 200, while car retailer Eagers Automotive (-4.9 per cent) lost ground as it warned port delays were affecting deliveries.
It expects revenue to be $1 billion higher in 2023.
Retailer Universal Store (-23.9 per cent) fell the most on
the All Ordinaries as it warned that trading conditions had further tightened in April and May, and it expects the subdued environment to continue into 2024.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has ended in the red with investors cautious amid the standoff over the US debt ceiling, and as iron ore prices fell this afternoon. The ASX 200 index dropped 0.7 per cent with most sectors in the red. Among the losers were miners, healthcare, technology firms and financials. Energy stocks led the gains on higher oil prices.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX falls as iron ore price drop pulls down miners

children.content: The Australian share market has ended in the red with investors cautious amid the standoff over the US debt ceiling, and as iron ore prices fell this afternoon.
The ASX 200 index dropped 0.7 per cent with most sectors in the red.
Among the losers were miners, healthcare, technology firms and financials.
Energy stocks led the gains on higher oil prices.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Concerns about the outlook for global demand and a stronger greenback have seen copper prices fall below $US8000 a ton for the first time this year. The metal is vital for producing batteries for a low carbon future, but the current state of play is more challenging with worries about a US recession, and a slowdown in China. Copper jumped above $US9,500 a tonne in January on the London Metals Exchange. But an increase in stockpiles, has seen the price of the metal come back down to earth. Copper prices are often seen as a sign of economic health as it is used in industries including construction, manufacturing, power and transport. However, ANZ economists think the sell-off could "incentivise China to increase purchases." "The import arbitrage has reopened, making shipping of the metal to China profitable."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Copper falls below $US8000 a ton

children.content: Concerns about the outlook for global demand and a stronger greenback have seen copper prices fall below $US8000 a ton for the first time this year.
The metal is vital for producing batteries for a low carbon future, but the current state of play is more challenging with worries about a US recession, and a slowdown in China.
Copper jumped above $US9,500 a tonne in January on the London Metals Exchange.
But an increase in stockpiles, has seen the price of the metal come back down to earth.
Copper prices are often seen as a sign of economic health as it is used in industries including construction, manufacturing, power and transport.
However, ANZ economists think the sell-off could "incentivise China to increase purchases."
"The import arbitrage has reopened, making shipping of the metal to China profitable."

image.altText: Angus Campbell in uniform speaks at a lectern against a black background

items.synopsis: Defence Chief Angus Campbell launches an attempt to remove awards from those who held command positions in the Afghanistan war.

title.children: Fresh push to revoke Afghanistan medals following Brereton war crimes inquiry

image.altText: A man with a moustache and goatee and wearing a cap standing in front of a building and smiling.

items.synopsis: A year after Tony Rowe was last seen in Darwin's suburbs, police charge a 29-year-old man and a 21-year-old woman in relation to his disappearance.

title.children: NT Police charge two people over disappearance of Darwin man Tony Rowe

image.altText: an Indigenous woman poses on a modelling runway

items.synopsis: Indigenous artists in Western Australia's East Kimberley talk up the future potential of fashion design, as young people explore new ways of expressing one of the oldest cultures on earth.

title.children: Outback passion for fashion connects young people with their ancient country

image.altText: A white airplane with the blue and red logo of Air France is pictured from inside the airport Paris Charles de Gaulle.

items.synopsis: France formally bans domestic flights on short routes that can be covered by train in less than two-and-a-half hours — a move aimed at reducing airline emissions.

title.children: France bans short-haul domestic flights that could be made by train

image.altText: A man runs the ball during a rugby league match

items.synopsis: Payne Haas is the runaway Dally M leader and has a claim to be the best rugby league player in the world. After four years playing for New South Wales, the time has come for him to dominate State of Origin football.

title.children: 'That's not always the way': How Payne Haas is changing his game to dominate in Origin

image.altText: Several bags of the drug ice on the ground

items.synopsis: Three hundred kilograms of methamphetamine was drilled out of a cargo shipment in Sydney in what police say was the work of a well-funded syndicate.

title.children: Federal police hunting crime syndicate behind elaborate $270 million Sydney ice bust

image.altText: A blonde woman in an orange sweater stands behind a cafe counter top.

items.synopsis: Renee Johnstone's Saturday trade usually covers her cafe's grocery bill for the following week. She and other business owners are fed up with what they say is a lack of accountability from energy providers.

title.children: Renee just lost $6,500 because of a power outage and she is demanding accountability

image.altText: Caitlin Bourke wearing her clinical scrubs leaning her crossed arms over her bed

items.synopsis: Students studying to become health professionals are increasingly struggling with the demands of unpaid placements as inflation rises.

title.children: Caitlin is doing unpaid placements across 24 weeks. She turns to buy now, pay later providers to afford food
